reviewText:
Alum is a beautiful game.

Everything fits together perfectly here, from the retro-pixel art style characters and foreground elements, to the hand-drawn painted backgrounds, to the well done voice acting, to the beautiful original music.

Gameplay is very much like the old Sierra and Lucasarts adventures, with the controls updated for a modern age: you can toggle between the (few, smart) actions with right-clicking, and scroll through your inventory items with the mouse wheel, so there is no need to constantly refer to the hotbar. The option is there though for people who prefer to play that way.

Puzzles in the game range from extremely straightforward to very challenging, but it never gets unfair. I was stuck at several points but for that the game has a built-in hints system. The hints given are never spoilers, instead just pointers to the right direction.

There are also some timed action scenes. The most difficult ones can be skipped, the game will offer this option after a few failures. But I think they're all doable.

The story in Alum is phenomenal. The main character goes through a full heroic journey, starting out as a nobody in a big city and becoming a true hero. Through the tale you pass through multiple locations, all very different but definitely fitting in the same world, and encounter a large cast of supporting characters and opponents, all again with their own voice.
The story managed to surprise me several times, and also made me smile a lot. It isn't afraid to pull punches, either. Lighthearted moments lead to emotionally shocking scenes where you really feel the loss... fortunately there is a happy ending, for those who can make it that far.

Alum really surprised me. I went in expecting a decent indie adventure game but what I found is one of the best games I've played in years. It is obvious that the developers had a real love for the game and they managed to deliver an almost perfect gaming experience.

I enjoyed every second I spent playing this game.
voteText: 53 of 61 people (87%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Oh boy.

Okay, let's start with just the game mechanics.  This is a point and click inventory-based adventure game.  There are only a couple of puzzles that take more than a minute or two to think about (the sequence on the boat comes to mind.)  In this regard, it's fun and rather intuitive.  However, many of the puzzles are rather inelegant.  By this I mean that elements of the puzzle-solving process are thrown in your face in such a way that it feels like you're reading a walkthrough.  This is not 'bad', and it's certainly not the whole game.  Why do I bring this up?  Because that lack of subtlety and feeling of being bashed over the head repeats itself in every aspect of the game.

But before I go through that, let's talk about art and music.  There are some really stunning moments.  The Vivit Oak seems like a place I'd love to visit.  There are one or two songs in the game that made me just pause and listen.  I want to bring this up before I complain any more, since it's a really strong aspect of the game.

Regarding every other aspect of the game - only play this if you're comfortable being forcefed religion.  It becomes apparent by the second chapter that this is a Christian game.  There is no good option but the one that is suggested by god.  You have an item that is essentially a direct line to god, and there are portions of the game where the solution to every puzzle is to ask god.  You wave your godcellphone in peoples' faces, and suddenly they see the light and are devoted to god.  God god god god god god.  The hero of the story isn't even the hero.  God is.  God sorta used some characters to share his godlove and godgod.  God!

I don't mean to bash this game or its developers.  I think it's great to have games that aren't afraid to connect with their version of spirituality.  The problem I have with this game is the same that I have with certain branches of Christian music; it's like drinking tea that has been steeping for approximately 38 years.  You don't have to lay it on so thick that it blots out the sun.  First it consumed the mechanics.  I had fun in the Vivit Oak.  The Rogation base was a little sloppy.  From that point on, I realized that god was the solution to every puzzle and I breezed through the rest of the game in an hour or so.  Then the heavy-handed religion swallowed up the storyline.  Toward the end, it was just people jackknifing between apostle and sinner.  The desire to show that god is love and light was so strong that character motivation and growth came to a screeching halt.  The 'main character' had a moment near the end where he acted in a way that wasn't precisely expected.  This is potentially a strong element to a story.  However, his reasons for doing so make no sense at all in the context.  It's hard to describe without spoilers, but I'll try: it's like walking across town to a bagel shop, then when you get there, marching in and going, The walk to this bagel shop took so long that now I hate bagels!"  I know what was trying to be conveyed
date: but it was so damn clumsy.\n\nIf I had to describe this in one word
recommended: that would be it: clumsy.  Not bad
hoursPlayed: just clumsy.  I hope the team that worked on this will expand a little bit
voteText: bring in some people with different perspectives.  Maybe have someone there whose only job is to say
votesHelpful: that story element you just wrote?  Maybe we should find a more subtle approach to implementing it."  I'm not saying
votesTotal: "Don't make a religious game."  I'm saying don't get caught in an echo chamber of religious ideas and lose sight of the 'game' aspects of it.  And as for the potential buyer
votesFunny: take a moment and ponder your tolerance for being beat over the head with religious ideals.  If it's not your 38-year-old cup of tea

reviewText:
Whoa! This game was beyond what I expected.

Everything was amazingly executed... The art, the story, the game play, the puzzles, the real time mini games, the characters, the voice acting, the music. Just top-notch all around.

During my play through, I could feel the game developer's genuine passion and love for the game. You just don't find that anymore in this day and age.

This game will touch on all of your emotions as you play through it and leave you feeling inspired to live for a reason.

What a gem.

reviewText: Alum was my first point and click game that I've ever played, and to be honest I was a little skeptical at first. I knew the basics to what a point and click game was, but it never really intrigued me. Although everyone wants to hear a good story, nowadays they're too busy being swept into combat arenas, focusing on killing each other for points. Satisfaction? Yes, but nothing can grasp what you will carry away from playing Alum, no matter what kind of game you may play. Usually in games you experience most of the story in the cut-scenes, causing players to blow through the actual gameplay just for those sequences, but in Alum you as the player really experience the whole story 100% of the time, and watch it unfold as you turn the pages in each decision that you make. Alum has a story for everyone to relate to, making it more of your story then the actual game's story. You play as Alum, but really you're every character you meet in this whole game. They are all so unique and full of life that they leave an imprint on you. It's not even just the characters that leave an impression on you, but the actual gameplay itself is so rewarding. Even in the little things that you do you'll find yourself grinning, but even then I was already smiling beforehand from just the pure enjoyment of the game. What this game has done for me is not only leave me applying the game's story to my own life, but also open up myself to the other point and clicks out there because now I honestly want to see if there are any that are just as good as Alum. I could keep going on and talk about how awesome all the artwork, music, voiceacting, gameplay, etc. is for Alum, but I think that's something you'll have to discover yourself.

reviewText:
In this point-and-click adventure you'll be playing as Alum, the citizen of a city governed by a seemingly benevolent man whose inventions keep the inhabitants safe from the cold land and shadow monsters known as the Lurid. Alum's wife is sick with the Vague, a disease that leads people to death by apathy: one day things change suddendly when he discovers there might be a cure for it and that the city might not be as perfect as it seems.

A throwback to the adventure games of old Alum sports some interesting puzzles and some strong starting acts but sadly declines a bit in quality as it goes and suffers from some ham-fisted exposition in its storytelling: it's still a decent enough game though.

PROS:

-the game world, with its mixture of technology and magic, is very interesting

-the story starts quite strong and sustains a good momentum in the first chapters

-intuitive puzzles

-you'll be meeting a wide cast of characters

-full voice acting

-great soundtrack

-good length (6-8 hours)

CONS:

-the graphics and art style feel a bit barren and aren't as detailed as other contemporary adventures

-some voice actors are quite poor

-a few (skippable) action sequences feel a bit out of place

-the last chapter of the game is quite a disaster suffering from counterintuitive puzzles (where, unlike most of the game, you're given no clues and have to proceed through frustrating trial-and-error), weird and sudden decisions from the main characters and some insipid turns in the story

-last boss" encounter feels clunky and is once more a trial-and-error affair

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=501325346

Alum starts very strongly
date: its world is well-designed and is quite believable
recommended: there's a nice sense of intrigue as you discover the secrets behind your city and the puzzles flow nicely.\n\nOnce you hit the 6th and 7th chapters though things change
hoursPlayed: one puzzle at the end of the sixth chapter was frustrating due to some very vague clues but this gets much worse on the seventh and final chapter where you'll have to fiddle with wires or bypass a trapped floor with no clues whatsoever to help you. This means trying over and over until
voteText: by accident
helpfulPercent: you realize what the developer had in mind or just look online for help. This sudden change in puzzle design is honestly very surprising and quite a letdown considering the previous parts all had intuitive puzzles were the solution was
votesTotal:
even spoon-fed to the player.

The story also starts to rely heavily on its not-so-hidden religious overtones and while this by itself isn't a problem it becomes one when certain scenes and decisions seem to have been designed more to act as a modern parable rather than serving the actual story: in the end the narrative suffers from it as it moves from the characters' actual feelings and experiences to a somewhat ham-fisted exposition on why hope and believing in an higher being is important.

Despite the disappointing finale Alum still has enough merits to be worth a playthrough though: due to the aforementioned problems I'd advise to wait for a sale or take advantage of the "pay-what-you-want" offer as long as it stands."

reviewText:
Game started out great, with a great story hook and great art. An hour and a half  later, I was no longer playing Alum, but rather 'Jesus, Your Lord and Savior - the Bejesusing'.

Don't get me wrong, I'm a Christian myself and am not bashing because I'm an antheist hipster. Just the way the overbearing Christian narrative is pushed in your face, without much subtlety or any game-specific adaptation and meaningful changes, feels very hamfisted. I understand the devs wanted to make a story about God and the way faith works but playing this feels exactly like being indoctrinated into some branch of protestantism and I don't feel this has a place in a point-and-click adventure game, especially one that advertises itself as something completely different.

It does the game a disservice, as the pixel art is indeed superb and the puzzles are enjoyable for the most part, without being too easy or too silly and frustrating. The theme could have been handled much more gracefully but the way it is, it feels forced and cringey, which largely ruins the fun.

reviewText: If there’s one major issue that I have with Alum it’s the voice acting. The characters typically sound inconsistent when you hear them and often it’s flat. Even if you take into account how one might sound with the “Vague” affecting them it’s still jarring. And the allegory can be a bit too “in-your-face” at times. I would have loved it to be a bit more subtle, but even so it all works in context. For a first time attempt at developing a game, and with such a low budget compared to other game Kickstarters, it’s still a worthy addition to the genre. Just nothing to write home about.\n\nhttp://cliqist.com/2015/05/18/finding-cure-alum/

reviewText:
Alum is a point and click adventure with heavy religious themes, but is not a very good game.  I got it for $1 off of Indie Game Stand, and I wouldn't recommend it for much more than that.  As always, it is important to note that this game DOES have failstates, but checkpoints you immediately before them.

The religious element of the story is essentially christianity, with a rename on most elements and a lot of the themes still present.  This isn't prima facie bad, and it could actually be a very interesting setting for a game... if it was well written, and this game wasn't.  I would expound on this further, but as it turns out another review sums up most of my problems with the game already.  All you have are usual christian cliches of faith, persecution, redemption, forgiveness, and so forth.  The game is neither robust nor well made enough to make up for its lack of original content.  Even if we give a huge benefit of the doubt to the game and its developers in assuming that this story isn't some sort of subtle preaching and take the game at face value, the face value is pretty empty.

This game is dedicated to all of our friends and family who have gone ahead to be with the true and living Unfeigned Altruist (Jesus Christ)" is displayed at the end of the credits.  I can't help but feel that this game was written specifically for a christian audience
date: a story full of good values and affirmation of your beliefs so that you were supposed to nod your head along to the religious elements with a warm fuzzy feeling inside.  It wasn't written to be original.  It was written to preach.\n\nStory aside
recommended: the rest of the game isn't much good either.  The puzzles aren't particularly interesting or clever.  The characters have no charm or personality to make you feel for them
hoursPlayed: and their voice acting is mediocre and almost always lacks the right emotion for the scenes (even taking into account the game's plot point of The Vague influencing this).  Locales are not particuarly interesting nor does any of the art draw much wonder
voteText: but the music is fairly passable.\n\nIts probably best to say that the game just isn't good.  Its not abysmal in any of these categories I critique it for (voice acting being the worst of the set)
helpfulPercent: but I didn't at any point crack a smile or feel like I was enjoying myself and I did give this game a fair shake.  The game is about 8.5 hours long.  Just pass
votesHelpful: there's plenty of other point-and-click adventure games with much better content from Daedelic and Wadjet Eye you'd be much better off playing."

reviewText:
Alum is a great and enjoyable game, despite the clear similarities with christian religion (which i didnt mind, its another world with their own believings. It does its work on bringing up the nostalgia for those who played the point&click games of the 90s.

Each one of the chapters consist on obtaining X item(s) in order to proceed. there is no random stuff in order to solve the puzzles, just talk and obtain clues in order to solve them.Sometimes you will need to do a lot of trips. If stuck it offers a hint system that can help you solve puzzles without giving direct instructions.

The story is entertaining. On the 1st 2 chapters it felt kind of empty to me, but from 3rd chapter and on, i found myself inside of it. They surely made their work on this. Also, GOBO.

Overall i would reccomend you to play the game if you enjoy good stories and not-too-cryptic puzzles.

reviewText:
Basic InformationTitle: Alum
Genre: Adventure, Indie, RPG
Developer: Crashable Studios
Publisher: N/A
Release Date: 15 May, 2015

Basic OverviewThis is a gem of a game. A basic Point & Click Adventure game that has a amazing story that keeps you wanting to continue through the entire game in one sitting if you have the time to. There aren't that many flaws in this game that I came across but there are still a few things that I would suggestion changing slightly.

Game PlayThis game is amazing. I'm not normally for one with point and click games but this one is a exception, it has a very intriguing story (Don't worry no spoilers here) that gets you hooked in and wanting play through the entire game (I didn't because I suck at puzzle type games). Obviously, with each Point & Click come with puzzles. Let me start off by saying that the tutorial actually blends in with the story and game play, which is really good because you normally have to go through a few text boxes before you can even start playing. This game tells you how to do things then you use it at that moment. Really good idea. I found the first chapter puzzles to be pretty self-explanatory then it started to get a bit over my head and got a bit more complex. Some of the puzzles are a bit to obscure to really know that, that was what you where suppose to do. Unless you hovered your mouse of it you wouldn't of found out how to do it. There was a few occasions this happened to me while playing this game, maybe that's just because I am bad at puzzles games. There is a hint one the options page that will help you if you understand what that means. If not then you will be walking around, hovering your mouse over every area of each place. None the less this is still a amazing game, it has some witty jokes inside and doesn't go over board when it uses them.  Each chapter of the game sets a atmosphere, or a question that you don't know the answer to. That really hooked me into each chapter that I played, this combine with some really intense moments in the game really sets it up to be a brilliant atmospheric game! The small cut scenes in this game look really good, you get the feel that you really are this person and you want to help them. Again, setting a terrific atmosphere which just made me want to play it more. The pacing in this game is very well done, it starts off slow with a few questions to the game, then by the end of chapter 1 (Took me about 30 minutes) it's then faced paced! A nice little element of the game that they added that I don't see often in other Point & Click games is the ability to show where all the exits are. This really does help you because sometimes you are unsure where they are, they aren't always obvious. The writing of the story and the voices of all the characters is very nice, the story is structured really well and the words they use just grab you into the game. I found that it's structured very well right at the beginning of the game.
Score (Out of 10): 9 - Although I would really want to give it a perfect 10, some of the puzzles are too obscure to figure out unless you have played the game before, I know it's suppose to be a puzzle game but some of the solutions to the puzzles went way over my head.

Graphics/Art StyleYou can see the type of graphics that are on the game through the trailer, it has nice pixel graphics that fit the game really well. Everything looks really nice and polished for pixel graphics. I feel like this game works really well with these graphics, and the whole atmosphere you keep with you through the entire game.
Score (Out of 10): 10 - Very well polished pixel graphics that work well with the game

Music & SoundsIn my opinion the music and sounds make the whole game how atmospheric it really is. There is very soft background music at times and every sound that you would expect to hear you would hear it, the songs that are played really suit the situations that you are in as well. It really makes you feel like you are in the game, and then when it gets to the emotional parts the music and sounds set in just right to get the most of out the game. Although I would like to hear a little more variation for the background music but that's just a little thing.
Score (Out Of 10): 9 - Maybe some more variation in background music.

ConclusionThis is what a Point & Click game should be. Very atmospheric, with all the music and the sounds, nicely crafted puzzles that (in my opinion) get a bit too hard as you went along the game and the graphics set the game up to be really good, and well fitting with the music.

For more reviews on a wide range of games, go and follow Lot's O Giveaway's curator group here.

reviewText:
Alum exceded my expectations. I thought it would just be a simple, pixelated, point & click adventure type game, but it's so much more than that. I felt for the character's actions and consequences. Alum captions a LucasArt's adventure game from back in the day, and that's marvelous. The pixelated graphics, the art style, is beautiful, even though it runs at a low resolution. It's able to capture the intended feel of the game's universe, a feeling of combat between good and evil. If you analyse closely Alum's story and atmosphere you find yourself comparing a lot of what's going on with religion. For example, The Unfeigned Altruist is Jesus Christ and The Invidious Umbra, can be shown as the Devil.

That's what Alum is all about, a fight between good and bad. You are Alum, a simple, normal, clumsy character that goes by everyday making daily deliveries as a job. His wife gets The Vague, a disease that's infecting everyone in Kosmos, a major city where the game starts. Alum is prepared to do everything to save his wife.

The question is, are you ready to lead Alum through this amazing adventure that features action, love, ice giants and references to Sniper Elite, Pacific Rim and Da Vinci's Demons? I think you are. So go ahead, buy this game, enjoy it's twists and turns, and I'll see you in my next review.

reviewText:
I can get over the strong Christian parralells, its set in a fantasy land, and i think its the perfect place for that stuff. So could treat it as a concept in the axioms inside the story, and not as a real meta truth which i believe it not to be, but could be as true as it liked in pixel land.

Although i was continually irked by the weak character devolpment, and ♥♥♥♥ easy puzzles just to have everyone advance the blisteringly obviouse Christion allegory, and to what gain?? To win over a small amount of maybie Athiest or agnostic retro pont n click enthusiasts.

It had no charm as a story unto itself, and got more and more bogged down with the bigger  accompyning 'wink wink' that the aulterist is actually God/Jesus, until it was unbearabley foie grase'd down your throat. It killed it, as every character was just a sound byte for that single Linear interest, which was an advert for the big bearded one.

Other characters where so suddenly shoe horned in to make a puzzle work it lacked all grace (ironically), or just used as a late hash attempt for some story to push forward the tepid narrative. Any result or drama surrounding them didnt matter to me a jot, and who voiced one of the kids a 20 yr old latin male? If they toned it down with the hard Jesus sell it could of still been good with a Christian template, it could of still of been enjoyed by thiest and Athiest a like, perhaps for the same reasons..a good story and game.

Unfortunatly the perpetual and ever increasing convertion intention, felt like accidently walking in to a Christian support group, or a street evangalising session all weakly clandestine behined a luke warm fantasy setting'. This made me want out the game, i didnt want to be lectured too on something i disagree with, as its purpose seemed to do that, kudos on not mentioning the obviouse simularity until the credits though, then the final slower folk could finally see it.

Paying for it, forced me to see it through as a result, and did make me see how totally contradictory ,bizzare and emotionally selfish faith was, and for that, it was an interesting venture. Next time its best to put a 'Christian game' clearely if its going to lecture in it, as this game will either preach to the already converted and just put everyone else off. Plus it was a ♥♥♥♥ game, i assume my swear word to the left will be covered by hearts it needs to be covered by symbals of excreta to be better represented.

reviewText: Alum is clearly an indie game put together by a small team, as is shown by the quality of its presentation. The graphics are pixelated a bit more than a lot of retro stuff, but if you're an old school adventure gamer, that shouldn't bother you too much. The audio is fine for what it is, but the voice acting is... not good. In fact, it's pretty lousy. You can tell most, if not all, of the voice actors are amateurs or first-timers. Still, the puzzles aren't bad, although after the first chapter, they've been bordering on too easy. The story, however, is where the game shines. It's something of a dystopia futuristic city setting, but there are enough odd elements to make it feel a bit fresher than average. There have been a few weird twists so far that have kept me guessing too, trying to figure out exactly what the heck is going on. I'm willing to put up with the games other weaknesses just because I'm so intrigued by the story. And for five bucks, it's not too painful of a purchase. Alum is a mixed bag, but on balance, it's decent enough to recommend.

reviewText: Alum features clever, varied and well-integrated puzzles, stylish retro graphics and atmospheric music, but is marred by persistent Christian preaching. In the hands of more proficient writers, this tale could have been a beautiful Christian allegory. However, as things stand, Alum drops the ball story-wise with unsubtle symbolism and one-dimensional characters. Puzzles are still a joy though...\n\nFull review: http://adventureadvocate.gr/gamereviews/item/alum-3

reviewText: This game is beyond my expectations.\nAlum is a great old-school style point&click game. If you ever played any Sierra or Lucas Arts game in the past, you will love the storytelling with great atmosphere and music. Puzzles are usually easy and enjoyable, I could finish the game with a few hints. Some may complain about the religious issues in the game but i didn't mind them because it's just a game with a fictional world. If you are not a graphics fan and looking for a retro style adventure I definitely reccomend this game for you.

reviewText:
The pixel graphics in Alum are beautiful and the music is nice, but that's really all of the good things that I have to say about this game.

This is a point and click adventure game, and follows the time-honoured tradition of the player needing to have the same ridiculous thought as the developer in order to progress. (Need to melt some ice? Fill a glass jar with water from a hot spring and then drive across a frozen tundra to where the ice you need to melt is located, somehow the water will still be warm!) There is an in-game hint system but it isn't very helpful. Action sequences are tedious, difficult and un-fun but thankfully if you mess them up enough times they're skippable.

Animations are very slow and a lot of walking animations and scene transitions (and some cutscenes but not all) are unskippable. There is a LOT of backtracking in this game, so you'll definitely notice it.

Voice acting is horrendous, there is one side character who speaks with realistic emotion and she stands out. There is a black character among the rebels whose voice and language verges on caricature.

As other reviews have noted, there is INCREDIBLY unsubtle religious stuff going on in this game, like the Altruist tells another character at one point that he died for her, and all of the language around accepting the rushlight will sound very familiar if you know any evangelical christians. This may or may not be a dealbreaker. Additionally, Alum is trying to save his wife from the Vague" - an illness that sounds kind of like depression
date: but his only evidence that she has it is that she fell out of love with him. I'm on chapter 6 and she has told him repeatedly to leave her alone and he's just super obsessed with her and it's a bit uncomfortable
recommended: though I'm sure in the end it'll be revealed that the devil corrupted her mind or something.\n\nAs mentioned
hoursPlayed: I have not completed the game
voteText: because I am on a puzzle in chapter 6 for which the hint is "distract Gwen" and I don't appear to have the means to do so."

reviewText: I'm really disappointed. This game started out so well, with good puzzles, an engaging story, and good pacing. When the Unfeigned Altruist first showed up, I really hoped the game would turn into a good metaphysical allegory I don't know something. But it just gets more and more preachy and it becomes unavoidably obvious that Unfeigned = Jesus, and the way the various characters interact with him gets more and more fervent and hard to ignore. I finally gave up in Chapter 6, I think most of the way through.\n\nSo, if the preachy aspect wouldn't bother you, then it's a good game. It does have some weird timed sequences but some of them can be bypassed.
